Pet peeve-
EST/EDT/etc in scheduling things throughout the day. The two are not the same. Are you using the right one?
EST= Eastern Standard Time (not daylight)
EDT= Eastern Daylight Time (daylight savings).
Some areas are EST, most are EDT. 1pm EST is not the same as 1pm EDT.

In some higher altitude areas, you *may* see 85 octane or even 85.5 octane. Again this is not E85, but 85 AKI (anti-knock index). Auto mfgs generally say 87 AKI is the lowest fuel you can use.

PSA: The yellow stickers you see at the pump- generally 87/89/91-93 are AKI (octane) ratings. Do not be confused with E10, E15, E85- which are concentrations of ethanol. There's no E87. There's no 15 octane. E signals ethanol content. Ethanol content over 15% is not AKI labelled.

@PatsFan_inNY Basically, the MFG dyno tested and engineered the vehicle's fuel and ignition map on 91 octane fuel (a higher octane fuel that you could theoretically advance the timing) with was not the baseline for the ECU. So your stock fuel map can't take advantage.
@PatsFan_inNY If it requires 91, there's no advantage to 94, since most vehicles that require premium do require 91 since that's the lowest octane "premium" available.

@1_Last_Thing In addition to a wideband O2, officially flex fuel vehicles generally utilize such a sensor as you describe, but going back to main point, this is about octane and cars not being designed or able to detect premium and take advantage.

@GunnarConsolWx @GasBuddy @41NBC @WGXAnews Unlikely as typically the gas station is one the one triggering a rack pull based on their tank. More than likely a station got into a price war with a nearby competitor. Happens often.

@1_Last_Thing I'm curious- can you name one production car with such a "fuel quality" sensor? Flex fuel cars often utilize a wideband O2, as I did, to adjust based on the AF ratio. More ethanol would run leaner, and the ECU would tune accordingly.

@roadmaven Ah the days before computers and OBD came into the world
I believe old Mustangs had switchable maps but that’s too hard for the public to understand.

But the opposite isn’t true- knock sensors don’t detect anything but knock. You can fill up with premium even if you don’t need it but the ECU has no way to detect it, nor does it have a separate fuel map for it.

Basically knock sensors can hear pinging/misfiring/pre-ignition/detonation and will retard the timing of ignition until the knocking stops. Once there’s an absence of knocking the car will gradually go back to the normal timing of ignition

That’s false. Modern cars can adapt if you misfuel with regular when needing premium via knock sensors that can detect audible knocking with low octane fuel. But cars have no such thing as “octane sensors”. Some cars can be designed with diff fuel maps for situations (like I did) https://t.co/dyllxdtksJ

Some higher performance cars (forced induction and luxury vehicles generally) are specifically designed to take advantage of higher octane and offer more power. Most cars can't take advantage UNLESS designed to do so! Don't waste you money!

With #gasprices being low, let me take a moment to remind you that buying premium gasoline if your car doesn't REQUIRE it, will net you nothing but money down the toilet. The reason is your car is tuned to run on X octane fuel & has no ability to magically increase output.

On average in the last 10yrs, the seasonal rise in #gasprices typically starts ~Feb 8 and lasts until ~May 2, a total of 83 days. During that time, average #gasprices have risen 54c/gal, with the smallest rise (17c) in 2017, and the largest (90c) in 2011.

2011: Jan 31
2010: Feb 15
